column4: There is lots of fresh food great select of unique things I haven't seen in a long time and things from other countries. There is some interesting artisans we met Linda who has nice art on old city photos and maps she even hand colors them. I had to have a map Seeing how I'm a tour guide. They even...

The market is a must see place for everyone visiting Saint John.The small restaurants provide relaxing,inexpensive opportunities for breakfast and lunch..not open for dinner.A visit to the Market is a step back into Saint John's rich history.As far as I am concerned,the Market is the number one attraction for all visitors to our city

Good spot to grab a hand made souvenir from Saint John. There are different crafts and jewelry plus fresh fruit and nuts. You can get groceries here and the fresh sea food is excellent.The public washroom is located on the exit to the left half way through the market. You exit at the top right at King Square where...

We like going to the City Market and seeing the different types of things offered. It is a interesting spot with lots of fresh produce, coffee, sweets and other things. Always a nice walk through and sometimes there are little tables set up with various vendors.

When I lived in Saint John, all of my grocery needs were satisfied by the market. Not only did I avoid over-packaging, processed foods and unknown additives, I got fresh, reliable produce, locally made and wholesome products and great conversation.Smells, tastes, colours and sounds that are unique to the market can transport you to a completely different zone, just...

My wife and I try to visit the market at least once a year. Although vendors come and go, the city market is one of my favorite places to visit. I especially enjoy the various pastries available to the public with my most favorite "Italian." From T-shirts to farm fresh meats to lobster/seafood to small bakeries to various wines to...
Great place for souvenirs, fresh produce and variety of local products. Great store owners to talk to, talented artists selling their wares.

Very cute place to go for both travellers and people living around. Have from vegetables to seafood, meat store, bakery, and all kinds of prepared food that you will 99% find what you need. Plus, the store keepers are usually nice and friendly.- $-$$- time: 10mins

This was our first stop on the St John tour and it was a perfect way to start as it offers food, drink, produce, snacks, handicrafts and local made items. I bought snacks unable in the USA and enjoyed for several days. A must in St John.
Great place for fresh produce, meat, fish and souvenirs for the out of towners! Just love the selection of prepared foods!
There is always something good to grab for a quick lunch. Love the market! From wraps, to seafood, to healthy salads, they've got it all.
Love a walk thru the market. Lots of different kinds of food and gifts and fresh produce. They even have a British section. There is a salad place and the food is amazing
Not what it once was 25% empty and nothing really unique or awesome anymoreI used to never miss the place when I was here, now it's pretty "meh"

I love the Saint Jon City market you can purchase anything and everything there. There is a fish stall that sells everything muscles lobster scallops battered fish etc. You can eat at the market as well

If you've never been to the city market, do yourself a favor and head over, you won't be disappointed! From the sites to the smells, it's intoxicating. You can find great values for whatever you may need or want.

I love urban markets like this one, and what the Saint John City Market lacks in size it makes up in charm. Looks like a great place to have lunch. We purchased some lovely cheap fruit and some delicious chocolate here. Well worth a stop. Doesn't take long to see if you're not having a meal.
I always love coming here. There's plenty of food whether you are grocery shopping or looking for a place to have lunch, you won't run out of options.

One of the most amazing places to visit. This market actually hosts about 50-60 small businesses from around the Saint John area. You can find just about anything you want or need, including some major crafts, food, delicacies from the sea and major friendly people.
Everything from typical tourist souvenirs to handmade artisan goods here. Big variety of food, also. Something for everyone. Be sure to go during the day. It closes fairly early.

Almost Every time my wife and I go to the city, we try to make time to stop in to the market. Crafts, food, coffee and conversation. What's not to like? You can browse at your own speed up the tight aisles or slip into some of the little stores for a snack or look at some pottery. Worth the...

This is not one of the largest market buildings we have been in, but it is very bright and airy with quite a variety of stalls to explore. Make sure you have a snack of lunch while there because there is a good variety of prepared food available.Stop in to visit and then take the underground passage assessed at the...

The sights, sounds, and smell of the market is amazing ! It's my favorite place to go in Saint John. Plan on eating while you are there and take home some fresh farmer's market food. It's also a great place to buy unique gifts.

This downtown market has scores of vendors and is frequented by locals as well as tourists. Interesting to see the range of produce, especially the apple varieties, and we picked up some handmade orange-scented soaps for gifts. A much, much smaller version of Reading Market in Philadelphia.
Approximately 30+ stands for food, jewellery, soap, artisan products, international foods, maple products, vegetables and fruit, the latter of which not all were of the freshest quality.

This place is very nice. Great varity of regular and local food items. Nice little food concessions with great sandwiches, etc.What surprised us was how clean the whole market is...even the bathrooms.Loved the experience.

My family was in New Brunswick as part of a cruise and I wanted to check this place out. I wish I wasn't watching my weight and food intake so much, because there was so much regional cuisine and food that I could've tried or sampled. While trying to be good I missed out. I would recommend sampling the food...

This is a great place to visit. The atmosphere is pleasing. The Market has a ton of vendors and lots of local businesses. I live here, in this city and visit often for lunch and such...I have several family members that visit from other parts of Canada and insist we visit the market every time they're here! Our Market is...

Wonderful market! We cruised to Canada and took a bus tour. This was one of our stops. Wonderful hand made items and locally grown produce. Lots to taste. There was even a small wine stand. Only wish we could have brought more home. The ceiling was beautifully decorated with balloons created by children which are auctioned off for charity.

St John is compact and the downtown area is easily explored on foot from the cruise terminal. Recommend you first walk along the waterfront to the little garden with a statue of a moose, pose by the quirky carvings of old men, then go into Market Square and across the bridge to the main shopping mall. At the far end...
The market gives you a break from the hustle bustle of the city. It is really an experience that you have to experience in person.

My husband and I love local markets. While the building may be interesting and historic, I didn't see much that interested me. Probably the "dolce" or "doles" was as interesting as it gets. The stuff is awful but some people love it. I did purchase a maple spread that was suggested for our salmon and it was fabulous. Other than...

Took awhile to find but glad I did. Not too big, but good variety of food, restaurants and local wear. I had fresh salmon and chips, very tasty. Even bought some local wine for later. Really enjoyed talking to the locals, very friendly.

The City Market visit was part of a private group tour. It was already crowded with locals as well as with tourists. The market sells meat, fresh produce, crafts, freshly prepared foods as well as souvenirs.In a tribute to the city's shipbuilding days, the ceiling resembles the inverted keel of a ship. Look up and you'll see the hand-hewn...

We stopped here as part of an excursion offered by our cruise ship. Really glad we did. Different places to have a bite to eat or shop for souvenirs or buy a warm hat made by a the lady who also sells them. Other well made gifts to be had also. I personally loved the painting of St John houses
We thoroughly enjoyed our stop at the market. All the vendors seemed fair and friendly. We especially enjoyed the pastries we bought at The Baking Stone. They were delicious!

This is a small but interesting city market contained stalls selling locally crafted goods and local produce. It also contains a lot of vendors selling food and is clearly very popular with locals at lunchtime. There is plenty of choice from fish, lobster, pizza's Chinese, sandwiches, soups etc. and all seem to offer very good value. With a lunch stop,...

The Saint John City Market is the oldest charter market in Canada and is housed in an old historic building, built in 1874-1876, which is open daily Monday-Saturday year round. It is very crowded probably because there's so much to buy there. Aside from the food, they also sold souvenirs and gifts. Such merchandise included crafts, glass figurines, cups and...
Some bargains, some locally made items - mostly imported tourist trinkets. Be selective and investigate - you may get lucky.

Nice little "shopping mall". About 2 blocks long with all the local vendors in there. Buy anything local, homemade or crafty from the area. Very friendly people. Can be walked through front to back in an hour.

This is primarily a farmer's market housed in a building that was constructed to look like an upside-down boat. If you're a tourist, there isn't a whole lot you can buy, in that the majority of the stands are produce and other perishables. We walked through and spent about 15 minutes here. That was more than enough.

Building is an giant upside down hull of a ship with 30 or so small restaurants and vendors inside. Anything from Jeremiah's Deli tasty sandwiches to Java Moose coffee to Baleman's fruit and veggie stand. Chatting with the local vendors is worth the visit ?
Very cute and full of variety. Something to walk through just to see. Local artists as well as imported items. Didn't get any food, but many people were. So I suspect it was good.

With a varied selection of food stalls, including meat, fruits and vegetables as well as an interesting array of arts and crafts, the Saint John City Market is a lively and fun place to taste local specialties while perusing hand made items made by artisans who were happy to talk about their work. Light and airy, with colorful decorations hanging...
Lots to look at quite a few people there on a weekday but all buying something everything from fresh fruit to exotic teas
Stopped here during a walking tour of St. John. We ate lunch here at a place that specializes in seafood (the fish and chips were stupendous). You can purchase a vide variety of stuff at the Market.

We dropped in to check out the City Market on the way back to our cruise ship. I wish we had allowed ourselves more time! The Market has foods and drinks, locally-made crafts, and other souvenirs of New Brunswick (made in China!)

Average market. Prices inflated for the tourists. Packed with tourists, especially when 3 cruise ships are in port. Maybe less busy in the am.If you want to visit an amazing market hit Granville Island Market in Vancouver BC

Just a beautiful facility. Look up and be amazed by the inverted ship hull. We enjoyed browsing thru, talking to local vendors and even purchasing some things. My favorite, and I wished that I would have bought more, was homemade soap by Wildtide Natural Soap. Dave was a pleasure to talk to. I only bought two bars of Secret Garden...

Make sure you look up from the front. Remember it was built by ship builders. The ceiling is the inside of an inverted hull.Great place to find local crafts, foods and other items you probably didn't know you needed.

Beautiful facility with very friendly people running each of the stalls. All the sights, smells, and sounds are something to take in. I was however quite upset they were closed on Sunday. That is my prime grocery shopping day.
Had a little bit of everything. Lots of food. People were friendly. There was a cruise ship in at the same time so it was a little hard to get around but overall a nice little spot to visit.

We were in St John as part of a cruise so enjoyment of the local produce and foods was limited but this market rivals some the best I've wondered through. Reminds me of the market in Lancaster Pa but this one is open daily. Was able to find some local crafts and enjoyed the bustle of the market. Perhaps not...

The vendors here sell locally made/grown items including fresh produce and food products, soap and toiletries, jewelry, ceramic items, home made children's clothing, placemats, knitted hats and art work. Be aware that only some of the vendors will take debit/ credit cards so you can get the correct exchange rate. I made the mistake of only taking American currency with...

We really enjoyed the Market. It was indoors which was great because it was raining. It was bustling with activity. There were many different vendors..some with less expensive stufff, made in China but also some really good hand made crafts, made locally. We bought two handmade reversible capes, made with wool fabric, excellent workmanship....paid just over $100. For each. Vendor...

Not too big or overwhelming, easy to handle, a wonderful place to go! It has a great mix of fresh produce, seafood and meats, as well as gifts and packaged food items so that there is something for everyone - the locals as well as tourists are more than satisfied! There are many places to eat while you're there. The...

Enjoyable place to spend an hour or so mooching about the stalls which sell all sorts from Dulse (local chewy seaweed delicacy) to live lobsters, clothes, Christmas trinkets et al. Very colourful and richly decorated with 100s hot air balloon type ecorations hanging from the trusses whilst we were there.

We spent an hour here on our way out of Saint John. There are lots of fresh vegetables, fresh fish ( even candied salmon) local artists, food, etc. Everything that you would expect from a local market of this size. Nothing special, but interesting nonetheless.

Love walking through the market. So much variety. Great food. Pleasant shop owners. Beautiful to see. A pleasant part of Saint John's history and in a great location for Cruise ship passengers to visit. Close to beautiful Kings Square.Good place to get fresh produce,meats, good meals and fresh coffee. A must see for anyone visiting Saint John.
There are so many options for things to eat. I had the best ramen I've ever had at a Korean restaurant inside the market.
City Market has a number of vendors selling a wide variety of goods. There are also places to get food to eat. It is a fun place to shop and eat. You name it, you can find it! Prices are reasonable.
Hectic at lunch time, but the international food choices are excellent. Fresh foods for shopping or very casual dining. Desserts, as well as plenty of trinkets for tourists.

You can get everything here. Gifts, souvenirs, groceries, lunch, dinner, Meat Market, Fish Market, clothing, etc, etc. Take the time to talk to the locals, they appreciate the support of their business and can tell you all about the history of the city and market.

Great building full of history! Has great vendors inside! Fresh fruit from the amazing Pete's Frootique! Those guys know their fruits and they always have great quality fruit n vegetables. They also have assortment of imported English deliciousies as well as other assortments. There are some great restaurants, great butchers and different seafood shops were you can get any sort...
Across the street from the Delta hotel. This is Canada. Fresh vegetables meats coffee pastries etc They got it. Place to see NB. A must see.
We walked thru the market and found lots of Canadian souvenirs. Place mats, syrup and fresh fruits and vegetables. Lots to see and buy.

We visit the city market every time we visit NB. My husband goes every day that we are in Saint John! Fun, lots of character, nice bakery, seafood and dulse! Love walking their his market and getting unique little trinkets and foods! A must see in NB!

This market has been around forever. You can get food and crafts. There are a couple of places to eat, or you can get stuff to take to the park across the street and have lunch outside. Take a look at the gates, which are originals. There are some nice crafts, and the fruit was excellent.

We were staying at the Delta hotel in St John. We walked to the market via the skyways.We enjoyed both the history of the market and the merchandise.It was a great chance to pick up some local and healthy items during our trip.This is a good place to grab St John souvenirs at reasonable prices.Great for...

Take the time to soak in the history of the Market! If I lived in downtown SJ I would do all my grocery shopping there. There are some great little places to eat there and some local artisans displaying and selling their works. Couple good places to get the tourist t shirts etc too.

We had a little time to spare prior to our boarding, so we strolled along the boardwalk and entered this place. We browsed through a few shops, had a quick bite and a cup of coffee. It was a good activity on a rainy day.

I have been five times in Saint John over the past 22 years. Saint John City covered market has been one of the highlights of each of my trips. The atmosphere, variety of shops, including a great coffee shop and several eateries, combined with the typical open stands of traditional markets such as those for bread, produce and fruit, souvenirs,...

This got many great reviews and I can't understand that. We went midweek and were very disappointed. Many booths were closed and vendors were just sitting around talking. It looks like this would be much better on the weekend when all the booths are open. There is a charge for parking in that area. They have food and trinkets for...

Nice little stop if you have time. It is very touristy but if you’re looking for nice souvenirs then it’s a good place to go, plus they have many little restaurants that serve delicious gelato and other deserts.
It's alright for a small town market. Fish and seafood were pricier than expected. Italian place had great foccacia and the hot table items looked delicious. Produce was okay. Worth a walk through
Take a stroll through the market and grab a bite to eat, a coffee or take some pictures. It does have a old world feel to it.
The market is set in a lovely old building and there are quiet a few different things to look at. Worth a stroll through when wondering round the town centre
Don't miss the City Market if you're headed to the center of St. John. Seafood, art and crafts, flowers, a good bakery and more. It's well worth stopping in.

We visited twice over a weekend in Saint John while staying at the Delta just across the street. The little person absolutely loved the French macaroons (an expensive taste, admittedly) and I got a good enough coffee. The place that used to sell pickled herring is gone, sadly, but there are lots of other things to see and taste.
The market is a great place to get a taste of the local culture.It is worth a stop if only for a walkabout lunch.
The city market is a place where you can get a variety of different foods vegetables and shop for local goods and serves as a entry point to a mall and other business's

I live in Saint John and go uptown at least 3-4 days a week. I visited. the City Market to buy some fresh veggies and ended up buying a butterfly windchime. It looks good at my back door in my new house.I not only love going in there to buy fresh vegetables or fruit and meat ! It holds...

This market is steps from my high school. I spent many days eating fruit and dulse from this market. (This is local dried sea weed that is set in the sun to dry and eaten by locals as a high iron food that is natural and comes from the bay of Fundy) The market has everything from local crafts to...

This is a "have to" stop when in St. John, if only for a walk through to see all the beautiful produce and local wares. It is the oldest continually operating market in North America. It is centrally located to a lot of other shopping & attractions also. Check it out - many different food vendors also!

While visiting Saint John, we stopped at the City Market one morning and liked it very much. It is basically a large farmer's market with a few craft places, sandwich and coffee shops. While we weren't shopping for fresh vegetables, we had a fun time looking around and seeing all the produce and food. Picked up a few souvenirs, too....

This was a pleasant walk around for us. As others have noted, it is much smaller than Toronto's, Philadelphia's, or Columbus Ohio's, but we recognize that Saint John is a smaller city. We had gelato, bought some trail mix, granola bars, and cookies for a whale watch the next day. As another reviewer noted, there were some homeless folks on...

We saved our appetite at lunch specifically for our visit to the City Market. We were anticipating something similar to St. Lawrence Market in Toronto but we were greatly disappointed by its size, the lack of variety for food options and the quality of the produce. Several of the booths or stands were vacant and it seemed like there was...
Not many places are left like this. Worth a visit if staying in Saint John . An eclectic mix of market produce, handicraft, souvenirs etc . All undercover and linked to the shopping centre.

During our Canadian vacation, we stopped and visited Saint John City Market. We really enjoyed seeing all the different foods and other items at the market. We bought some delicious bread, enjoyed some great cannoli's and enjoyed learning about the local fish and lobster.

Lots of vendors to see. Food is fresh and looks great. Tasty as well. Plenty of souvenirs to purchase for family and friends. Nice city park with buskers close by, so nice, relaxing outing for the day. Spend as little or much time as you need to enjoy the downtown core! Well worth it!

For me this isn't only an attraction, this is a way of life for me. Along with being able to find just about everything I need, I buy all my groceries here.....every week....I truly love keeping it local and by that I mean supporting within the Maritimes in many instances; berries in season, lots of varieties in fruit and vegetables,...
I love going to markets and found this one quite enjoyable. There's a few restaurants inside that accomodate everyone. The building was beautiful.
Visited on Friday on our wander through the downtown area. A nice market, lots of arts and crafts, gelato, smoothies, produce and meats. A good spot to visit.

Visited on a Saturday morning around 9 a.m. Perhaps I am spoiled by Montreal markets, but this place was quite dull. A dozen or so stands, some selling fresh-ish (not necessarily local, produce) fishmonger, meats, souvenir trinkets. Not the typical bustling morning market I am used to. It's like a microcosm of the economic depression afflicting the entire city.
What a bright colourful, unique old building. Loved the wood ceiling. Lots of vendors to see and check out the local market stuff. Oh and a good breakfast too.
Enjoyed our visit to the market. Picked up gifts for friends, enjoyed a great coffee had something to eat. Fresh vegetables, local wines, gifts, something for everyone.

We walked downtown and saw this market so we stopped. Well located market when you are walking downtown! I was impressed by how colourful and diversified this market was. The building is old but well maintained. When I walked in, I was charmed by the smell and the diversity of products. I bought two t-shirts in a stand in the...

We stopped here when we were in town as we had a few hours to kill before a wedding. This is a delightful little market. I've been told that it is the oldest continuous market in Canada.It's a relatively small market, but there is a fantastic variety of products from locally made food and crafts, to ethnic eats and...
Beautiful inside some shops and 2 fruit vegetable venders, great coffee! Local wine and seafood available but not much variety.

A nice little market, but given it's ranked #3 on the Things to Do list on TripAdvisor, we were disappointed; it's very small. We did have a nice sandwich from Jeremiah's Deli and some great treats from The Baking Stone.

We stopped here several times while we were in the city. The market is small, but had a good selection of produce and prepared foods. There were the requisite souvenir shops as well. We were able to pick us a tasty breakfast at the Moosehead Cafe as well as sandwiches for another lunch. A local winery has an outlet there...

It is a nice place to meander around and an iconic market in the centre of town. WHile not huge of the ilk of Ottawa's Byward Market or St. JAcob's Ontario it has its own character with many merchants having been there for several generations. It has its butchers shops, vegetable & fruit stalls and crafts and collectibles from the...

Situated right in the heart of downtown Saint John, the market provides an eclectic offering of goods, both local and imported. It is an ideal location for visitors from the many cruise ships that dock nearby from late spring to mid autumn providing interesting things to take home with them. There is always a hum of activity going on with...

We shopped and had lunch at the City Market and enjoyed it very much. There are many shops in and the Market if you don't mind walking a little. We ended up walking along the Harbor passage and it was beautiful with all the path-side gardens in great shape. Try it sometime!
There's a lot of good stuff in this market. Fresh produce, coffee and tea, a bakery, small eateries of all kinds, and some craft vendors. Tables to eat outside, and a lovely old building.

Reminds me of Faneuil Hall/Quincy Market in Boston, Massachusetts. This place has a number of eateries and a few shopping stalls. A great place to grab a quick and casual bite to eat. With a park across the street to enjoy your food. We got some great sandwiches and then went back in for a pastry. YUM!

This is a great place to grab a bite to eat, pick up local delicacy items or fresh groceries, or find a gift for someone back home. Look up! The building was built by shipwrights, so the veil resembles the bottom of a ship.

This is a nice market to visit if you want to spend a bit of time checking out the local vendor wares. It offers fresh food and tourist items to purchase if you are interested in finding take home gifts. It is quite small compared to some we have been to but a good place to walk through and get...
I love this place. The individual food locations are great. Lots of gift ideas for the tourists and local people.I try to go there at least once a week to support the local businesses.
It was a little smaller than I expected. But it was a neat experience. We walked around & looked at several of the vendors items. Then finished off having lunch at one of the fish markets

Visited this nice spot, good stop when downtown. It is filled with lots of local vendors for foodies mostly. Lots of local foods. There are only a couple of things that are for pottery and related things. The whole market is quite loud and busy on weekends, but is still a great place to waste some time (and a lot...

Every time I'm in Saint John I make a special effort to visit the market. I love the beautifully maintained space, with its stalls full of produce, seafood, meats and handmade goods. Even the rafters are usually full of community arts and crafts, lending a sense of whimsy. As local or tourist there's much to tempt you...Billy's Seafood shares the...

Can't cover this unique attraction in one review. Almost every type of food and souvenirs. We sampled Dulce---dried seaweed. Not my favorite. But samples of real maple syrup, lobster tail pastries, freshly made éclair's (shaped like a lobster) with heavenly vanilla cream filling. It's the oldest operating farmer's market in Canada and is truly a wonderful way to spend some...

One of our last stops in Canada before heading back to the US was here at the City Market. So colorful and full of all types of foods. It isn't real large but there is enough here to satisfy most everyone. We purchased incredible fresh smoked salmon, custom made salads, fresh OJ (real) and desserts. All excellent except one dessert...

Really adorable with a good amount of vendors but still isn't even an hour's worth of stuff to look at. Great selection of fresh produce and cute knick knacks though. Bought beautiful art prints from a kiosk in the middle row.

We have been to the market several times and it doesn't get old. Whether you want a cup of coffee or a cute souvenir this is the place to go. Lots to look at and see. I highly recommend this if you are visiting uptown Saint John. From there you can walk to the museum....the 2 places in Saint John...

I have gone to the Market several times while visiting Saint John. However, this time on a recommendation from a local, my travel companion and I ate at the Wild Carrot Cafe. We ordered the whale of a salad and it was really a great choice. Even the half a whale was big enough. You got two types of lettuce...

Variety of goods, seafood, baking, art, crafts and on and on. Just an experience walking along the aisles. This is a landmark and a must visit - I was here a couple of years ago and I honestly thought the variety and bustle was better but it is still a "go to" place.
This market has local produce, baked goods, meats, seafood, etc. as well as hand-crafted items and tourist items. The restaurants are the best values we found, although seating is at a premium.
A nice mixture of farmer's market and local artisans combined. Good coffee on the way in, good food, fun crafty stuff.

We enjoyed seeing all of the products . .of which many of them were home grown or made. It is a big market encompassing about one city block . . just opposite Kings Square . .and very near the Delta Hotel. Worth a visit!

This historic market is one of the oldest, if not the oldest market, in Canada. The atmosphere is unique and particularly relaxed and friendly. It is an Agora, a meeting place for people downtown. Everyone knows everyone. No one is a stranger there even if it is his first visit.The produce and meats are fresh, the crafts are local,...
If you have time this market is worth a visit. It is very much for locals and is open everyday.It had a mixture of fresh produce, food to eat, crafts and souvenirs. Parking downtown is easy and cheap

This covered market is open daily, with fresh produce of the highest quality. The stalls are well kept and offer a wide range of food items, baked goods, soups, buns, and sandwiches. The seafood is beautiful and very reasonably priced. Supposedly, the building was constructed by shipbuilders who used the same techniques employed in hull construction. The roof of the...

This is a collection of vendor booths under one roof. There is quite a variety of food and non food items for sale. There is a moose head over the entrance to the restrooms. A long glass covered seating area is located on the side of the building.

While I do enjoy shopping at the various vendors here for vegetables and meats it is also a great spot to grab a sandwich and a bowl of soup at one of the many fine spots for a quick bite. Ample seating is available. A nice old market. Every city should have one like this.
Fantastic place in the middle of town. Vendors with fresh foods, crafts and great restaurants with the freshest of ingredients. Don't miss if you are in Saint John!

I don't know if Saint John locals really appreciate the awesomeness that they have with the City Market. My wife and I visited on a Saturday at noon...which would normally mean complete chaos at the Halifax or Moncton markets...and it was practically empty.Some fantastic local food options available, fresh produce and fish, and local art are available. If you're...

The Saint John City Market is the oldest continuing farmer's market in Canada, with a charter dating from 1785.[1] Located in Saint John, New Brunswick and completed in 1876, the current market building has a unique roof structure that resembles an inverted ship's keel. Made of wooden trusses, the structure was reportedly built by unemployed ship carpenters of the day.[

City Market in operation since built by shipbuilders. Is Unique in design- an upside down ship's hull! No center pillars or posts to hold up the roof. Ship's bell has been rung at beginning and end of work day since 1700's. I actually got to hear it- at close of the day! It does have some art and tourist wares...

We were expecting a rather large marketplace with variety. We had been to a marketplace in Barcelona Spain and were very impressed. This was not at all on par. Though there were some restaurants within the marketplace, the offering was limited. The vegetables and fruits didn't seem that fresh.
Did actor of the market. Lots of veggies and meats but doesn't help when your staying in a hotel. Thought there would be more local art and crafts!

You can travel anywhere in the world and enjoy the essence of culture by shopping in city markets. Saint John City Market can rank right up there with the rest. Yes, the City Market is the soul of our harbour city, Saint John, NB...the history, the colours and aromas, it's people from all walk of lives and welcoming smiles. We...
Has all the basic groceries in a charming old building. The location is good also, plenty of street parking meter parking
Def a cool place to check out for locally sourced products, overall prices were a it higher than a average but a cool place to check out non the less.
You would like the charm of this market. They are still cutting fresh meat daily and offer a wide variety of items to purchase from food to merchandise.

I always like the atmosphere at the market. You can't go wrong wandering through. You never know what there will be to purchase or who you might run into. The food is a MUST......it makes the experience memorable.

We visit St. John frequently and we go tinge market EVERY time! The variety of food, crafts, and vendors is excellent! You can walk through the market and head to the shopping mall without ever going outside. My family loves the market. We love trying the different breads and the different products from Britain and other international cuisines.

The Saint John City Market is a truly wonderful piece of New Brunswick history. The impressive ceiling showcases the cities shipbuilding past. The vendors are varied and extremely friendly. It's a great place to shop, great ethnic foods, local artisanal ciders, cheeses and seafood. Not to be missed, especially on a Saturday morning with local entertainment.

We were on a cruise up thru New England to New Brunswick and Halifax, NS. Got off the ship in St. Johns and tour the Big Pink Sightseeing bus thru the city. He let us out at the City Market area and we walked around inside the building for about an hour. Lots of local stuff to see and do....
Very old market. Beautiful building built on a hill. Something for everyone in there from crafts to specialty foods to fresh fruits, veggies, meat, seafood etc.

It was a short walk from our stay at Chipman Hill Suites, and worth a look. Had a great variety of fresh fruits, vegetable, meats, baking etc. We had a nice breakfast at one of the little booths there and was very impressed with the food they were able to prepare in such limited kitchen.Bought some local foods and...

We would probably try this marketplace again. Our experience was offset by being there when the world's biggest cruiseship was docked, and many of the people on it were there so it was packed and generally pushy, veering on rude in some cases. Perhaps because they had a time limit on getting back?We did find some nice fridge magnets...

Our cruise ship was at port on Canada's Thanksgiving. Fortunately, the city market was open. Unfortunately, a lot of vendors were closed for the day. The vendors that were there had some unique jewelry, which I loved and bought! Colorfully decorated. Worth the time to stop in and walk around!

Easy walk from the port. We were a little disappointed by the size and the lack of local people. It is more a place where tourist go to buy trinkets. There was an mix of souvenirs, produce/food, and artwork/artisans. It was interesting to walk around but can be done in no time. We probably would not go back if we...

Variety is the bottom line for this market. Not only was there a wonderful variety of fresh food, but also small eateries, a wine merchant, bakeries, ethnic food, local processed foods, a seafood market, gift stalls, etc. We stopped into this market daily for the 3 days we spent in Saint John. We had dinner at Billy's seafood, which operates...

We were able to find some great local crafts here. They do sell a lot of fresh food and produce, but there are goods and souvenirs as well. The coffee shop offers free wifi (don't recall whether it was From the coffee shop of just accessible from there but if you need to check email, grab a cup of joe...

We found the market after a local recommendation... Great finds include low-cost and delicious lobster rolls from Lord's, beautiful art on cards by Jessica Doyle, gorgeous pottery mugs at The Butcher's Daughter, etc. The food smelled wonderful and the fruits and vegetables looked fresh. Most of the merchants were very friendly and welcoming to the customers. However, we did encounter...
Always a great time wandering the market on a Saturday morning. lots of great food and fresh local produce and wares.

This was my first trip to the Saint John City Market and it was great. Not nearly the produce selection I'm used to in Halifax NS, but our market is much much larger and serves a much larger populaton. For the size of SJ this is an amazing market.For Maritimers it is fun to visit the original Pete's Frootique...

column4: Old City Market has perhaps 100 or more vendors in a high-domed glass space, been there since the 19th century -- seafood shops excellent, take-out food, the awful dulse dried seaweed which some Nova Scotians eat like potato chips. We stuck with salted fish and aromatic soaps.

The candied Maple salmon at Lord's is delicious. They do their own smoked salmon as well which is amazing. Pizza by the slice for $3 at Sisters pizza shop. Fresh produce from Baleman's or Pete's Frutique... fresh fish, meat, and chicken. Samosas, gelato, and the like. Also a variety of art, handcrafts and children's clothing.
Very small compare to other markets I visit but very cute! Worth the visit to taste what the local eat and to look at the butterflies on the ceiling.

Perhaps it hasn't changed much in many years, but that is part of its charm. Buy some dulce or extra old cheese. We bought a nice-looking sirloin roast today, can't wait to cook it. Try Pete's Fruitique at one end, and Billy's Sea Food at the other end. Lots of little cafes to grab a bit.

Most cities would do anything to have a magical spot like this located in the heart of their city core. The Saint John City Market offers everything from lunch & coffee to groceries & arts. The best part is that most vendors are experts in their craft - whether being farmer, butcher, baker, fish monger, whatever...A wonderful place enjoyed...

We loved this market. It smells delicious once you walk in the door. So many fresh foods and different cultures to taste. We went through twice in one day. First about noon hour. We purchased and tasted fresh made gelato. O M G....so good. $4.75 size dish with 3 different flavors. They let you taste test before you buy. We...

I really enjoyed this place. There were a variety of vendors: food, clothes, trinkets, etc. The prices were quite reasonable and certainly a lot better than what I expected to find in a touristy area (it's located right next to a Delta and a Hilton hotel). Although it is not particularly unique or distinct when it comes to markets, I...

Great fresh food vendors in a cute indoor location. You can get fresh produce, meats, seafood, wraps, pizza, Korean, and other good stuff for lunch. If you are in the mall complex, bypass the fast food in the food court and head up to the Old City Market for much better food!

Recently,I visited Saint John and I enjoyed this lively market.I liked the variety of foods that were offered there.I also appreciated the reasonable prices that I paid for good food.Since Saint John is a port city,there were plenty of opportunities to enjoy fresh fish,seafood,and dulce .

My wife and I had some time on our hands and took a stroll through the market. It is great. Clean and welcoming. With about 40 vendors it is not huge but has a good selection. In fact, my wife bought some blueberry food item for gifts, sauce, jam, etc. I bought a photo which had been lasered onto canvas....

in the middle of St. John, this market has artwork, a ship's hull design and interesting architecture all around it. As far as markets or farmer's markets go it isn't big but it has a good mix of food, wine (yes a NB winery sells its wares there) and crafts. It opens early. A very pleasant Saturday morning.

I was aware of this area before coming to Saint John but we were running low on time but managed to squeeze in a trip here. We met a tour guide by accident and he told us about the roof. Notice that the ceiling resembles a ships hull. Well it was made by ship builders long ago. There is plenty...

I could not pass up visiting St. John without stopping at this historical market. Parking is pricey, with street meters all around. Fresh bread, fruits, vegetables, meat, deli food are all around. The best place however, was the fish market. I cannot remember the name, but the cold smoked salmon was the most flavorful fish I had tasted this entire...
We love the market. Every time in St John we go to visit the market. It's history that we don't get in Northern BC.
Great atmosphere, great service in this Market. Look up and take notice of the upside down ships hull that is the roof.A landmark of Saint John and Canadian Heritage.Enjoy!!
I go here almost every day and it's one of my favourite places. If you come to SJ you have to go to the city market.
I believe it opened in 1855 and it has been in operation ever since.A great variety of locally produced foods and crafts plus some boutique type shops.

The Old City Market is very comparable to Faneuil Hall Marketplace in Boston. Inside a classic old building this market has every type of ethnic food and many fun shops. My wife and I purchased some maple syrup (produced locally) and some fun British soda. The building itself is also part of the allure. If you go to Saint John...

A visit to St. John is not complete until a stroll is taken through its City Market. This is a happy place with a variety of items --- from food to crafts ! This market building is unique & full of charm !Enjoy !

City Market is a great place to get vegetables, meat or cheese. There are several small delis there too where you can get fresh sandwiches or salads. There are also vendors selling empanadas, somosas, baked goods, gelato. Additionally, there are jewelry and novelty vendors. This is a fun place to explore and shop.

We where on a tour and didn't have enough time to spend here, and could have. The building ceiling is shaped like the bottom of a boat and is decorated with pictures of fish that the local children made and hung from the ceiling, so cute. There is local fish mongers, locals selling crafts, art work, paintings, jewelry, candy, freshly...
This busy market is a nice place to browse and eat. If the cruise ships are in the harbour, then prepare for a crush of humanity.

Love Saint John Central market. Cities with thriving city central markets are great places. There is a minimum of tourist tat, and an emphasis on fresh produce and some great little eateries. Java Moose is a coffee spot serving up great doughnuts and terrific coffee.

All I can say is go see it, buy stuff, and enjoy the downtown. Great stop. We were able to buy fresh produce, seaweed (yuck), and muffins all in the same place. The food vendors were all made from scratch places that would be five ball if on their own. Wow.
We bought cooked lobster, smoked salmon, cheese there for lunch later and it was excellent. Fun to see all the wares for sale.
This was a great day at the market. Get a Lobster Tail at the bakery. It's a cream filled pastry. The sights and sounds and smaells are amazing. Don't forget your camera.

The City Market combines both touristy & practical items. You can get souvenirs but also bakery products, fish & chips, Italian food and much more. And don't forget to look up at the unique ceiling construction, similar to what you would find in an old ship. That's because the builders of the market were shipbuilders as well.

A stroll through the market is always interesting. Lots to look at. Sat am the market is particularly busy. A couple of nice lunch spots...opportunity to try something new-different. Crafts & products from local crafts people...coffee....baked goods...fresh fish...a butcher with freesh meat. If you are a "people watcher, the market is always an interesting spot to hang out...or pick up...

I learned from the visitor center that this is the oldest farmers market in Canada. When you look up, it's designed to look like a ship. My hometown (Lancaster, PA) has one of the oldest farmers markets in the USA so it was interesting to compare the two. Old City Market was bright, colorful and open. Although there weren't a...
Fresh produce, butcher shops who will cut to your preferance, fresh seafood, lots of hip little shops selling local arts and crafts. A great old building. Nice ambience.
Went on a rainy day enjoyed the market and walked to some of the parks/shops, we enjoyed ourselves! Lots of people, a hugh cruise ship was in the harbor!
Very colorful and clean. Not a huge assortment of produce and meats, but a nice diversion when strolling around St. John.

We stopped by the market on a cruise ship tour after walking trhough two other small indoor malls. We enjoyed the Java Moose coffee with the free internet in their small seating area. Most of the market had fresh fruit, vegetables and fish which were were not interested given we were getting back on the ship. I assume it would...

We stopped here in the morning before leaving Saint John and I'm glad we did. The market is really colorful and has a lot of history associated with it. I'm also glad we stopped because I found some really cute souvenirs here - there's a little something for everyone. The most difficult piece about visiting the market is parking...but there...

Not too many places still have city markets like this anymore so definitely worth a stroll through especially if you have children who have never seen an old style market place.Nice mix of merchants. Some fresh food, some prepared food, some baked good, some artists and crafters. The market isn't huge, three aisles running the length if I remember...

This is a great place to walk through to see the produce sellers and cute food stalls. You can't go wrong no matter where you eat. Take a look at the ceiling which mimics a ship. You can't go wrong rain or shine. This is another of Saint Johns jewels!

Saint John City Market is a great place to have a quick lunch any day of the week or you could enjoy shopping for fresh produce, meat or arts & crafts with the many locals that visit the market weekly. There is lots of variety in the vendors that sell here and lots of samples are available for people to...

I really like the architecture and dropped by for a visit during a meeting. There were few people around, some stalls were empty (folk on vacation?) and there was little that cried out to be purchased. Left me feeling flat. In contrast I was at the Fredericton Market on the following morning and despite lousy, snowy weather the place was...

I don't care what you're looking for, one of the vendors probably has it. Smoked fish on a stick? No problem! A hat with moose ears? You betcha! Lobster balls? Yes, but it's not like it sounds...A nice diversion and a chance to thaw out a bit if it's chilly outside!

If you visit Saint John you must go to the Old City Market. There is so much to see and buy- crafts, souveniers, and so much more. Fresh fish, seafood, fruits & vegetables. Many small restaurants to choose from. It's in a great location and you don't even have to go outdoors to get to the mall.

Something for everyone here. We stopped twice... once for breakfast at a restaurant in the center and browsing and shopping. Then, again the next day for mid-morning coffee and more souvenirs. Local foods, good meals, hand-crafted jewelry, t-shirts and hats, candy, pastries, take-out food, and more.The architecture is stunning, with a high, bright ceiling (made of a ship's hull),...

see the Old City Market. We went out of our way to get there and it was very disappointing. There was nothing of the color and bustle of the Seattle Market. It was small, with everyday vegetables and fruit and nothing was particularly attractive. The souvenirs were ordinary; you could find them in any souvenir shop. The food offered was...

We went to Saint John on a cruise. It was a rainy day so we decided to take the Pink Bus tour, big mistake, it's pricey and the tour took us through many run down areas in town. So we got off at the Old City market bus stop. My wife and friend did some shopping and we had some...

I went with my husband, we visited this place, is really nice and you can find many souvenirs, and shops from the city if you want. It´s very clean and nice. There is a real market in there with vegetables, fruits, and many Maple Syrup that is famous. If you go to Saint John, don´t miss it. We wen on...

This old indoor market was interesting as it appeared that it was also a favorite stop for the locals, not just the tourists. It had a wide range of fresh and prepared foods - including dulce - a seaweed that is processed into a snack like chips. It also had handcrafts and other local products. The architecture of the old...
We didn't buy anything here. But we still enjoyed the stroll through this market. Artwork, trinkets, souvenirs, fresh meats, vegetables, etc. Vibrant colors; lots of energy. A fun 15 min.

I love the City Market, it is filled with many interesting people. Great to grab some food or a treasured keep sake from the city. Due to it's unique design, colour, and activity; it is one of the most visited and photographed places in Saint John.On cruise ship days it is also the most packed place in the city....

This market has typical market items - meats, fruits, vegetables. But we went there in search of something new and different and boy did we find it. I can't remember the name of the place - they sold sandwiches and such. There was a refrigerated case with some yummy chocolate things. Who can resist Chocolate?? These treats were in the...
Amazing architecture and history with modern day style. Beautiful boardwalk and wonderful outside restaurants and terraces.

The City Market is a cornerstone of the downtown Saint John shops. It is a great place to meet people and to pick up some great cuts of meat, seafood and produce, all the while supporting the local producers.

Very busy market place. Easy to walk to from cruise ship (St. John is very hilly, but not too difficult to walk). Loved the unique style of the building & the friendly vendors. So many tempting foods and fantastic pottery, jewelry, and art made from recycled "trash". A couple vendors sell what I call tourist junk. There were a few...

I liked that it wasn't packed and got some great dulse and baklava (not something you have every day together!).I disliked nothing really other than that I wished more people went to enjoy this wonderful landmark.

Small stands were set up with local cheeses, produce, meats, seafood, etc. Not just a farmer's market, there were stands with pottery, recycled products, linens, etc. Everyone was very friendly. No pressure to buy. Java Moose coffee at one end serves great local roasts. Billy's Seafood Co at the other end is a great seafood restaurant.

You find things there that are different from other farmers market. Things made from recycling, other hand made things very nice and at an affordable price. Wish I had had more time to look closer at everything.
Nice place to stroll and check out the crafts. Highlight of our visit was eating a small tub of cooked lobster for a reasonable price and a 5 scoop ice cream milkshake.
It was a wonderful place, I grew up in Saint John and had not been back in many, many years, so to relive my sat. mornings adventures was just the greatest.
Best way to spend a Saturday morning in town! Wonderful local entrepreneurs with exotic foods, crafts and delicacies.

We had a wonderful time looking at shops and there were local crafters selling their crafts for very reasonable prices. If you are going to walk, there is a lot of uphill walking. A simply beautiful place to stop spend some time.

several reviews here are for the Market Square mall, not City Market.this is a great, original city market that contains vendors of fresh meats, fish, fruit, and vegetables. Many do have some kind of take-away food item available. The structure is utilitarian, but in an attractive and authentic way.It's located downtown in the historic area, just block from...

I visited the Old City Market with my wife when our cruise ship stopped in Saint John. Disagree that this is just for tourists. We were camping and it was a rainy day so we decided to check out the market. We bought some fresh fish and fresh vegies, some fresh bread and had a feast. Disagree with reviewers that say this is just a tourist trap. There is a variety of fresh food items of very...
This is great place to find some lunch from one of the korean food places or from one of the sandwich shops but otherwise it is mostly a load of over priced items designed for tourists.

This just a place cruise ships to come in and the passengers to connect bus ,taxis and other means to tour the rest of the city . To come by car your charged $1.75 an hour for parking The mall is something you find in any city , Loved the Anglican Church opening is doors and let people view the...

I love going to the market on Saturday mornings when I can. You can buy Montreal Style bagels from Pete's Frootique, there is fresh juice, vegan food, fudge, seafood, restaurants, dulse and everything else in between including fresh flowers and wine.Whenever you get the chance, definately take a stroll through even just to look at the amazing variety and...

The Old City Market is just that, old and a City Market. It has functioned pretty much as it does now for well over 100 years...Locals go there daily to buy fresh meat, fish, produce, cheese, baked goods etc. It probably looks very similar to how it looked back in the 1800's.There are also some products that would...

The market was rather smaller than I thought it was going to be, I walked through it in just about 30 minutes. They have fruits and meat, as well as art work, ect. I couldnt buy and meats or fruits since i was on a cruise. It was nice to look at, nothing I would really buy besides a bottle...

The only thing I purchased was from the bakery. Over priced but really good! Everything was too expensive and other than the produce and meat it was like a small scale flea market. Mostly worthless junk. It's worth a walk-through to say you did but spend your money elsewhere.

You could peruse the aisles and stores here for hours if you wanted to (and I wanted to!). We bought some fresh pollock and some smoked salmon (SO GOOD) from the fish place closest to Java Moose and some artichokes from Pete's Frootique (can't get them in Amherst, NS!). Also picked up a few bottles of wine from the Winegarden...

The City Market is worth going to. it is bright and festive. There are lots of fruit and vegetable vendors, butchers and seafood sellers, artisans and gift-stores, etc. It is a fun vibrant place to walk around. You can get prepared food, or stock up on provisions to cook later. The food is generally local and high-quality.Reminds me of...
The paninis and steak subs at the Old City Market are awesome! Don't forget to look up at the ceiling when you're there - it's the hull of a boat turned upside down.

The old city market is more than just that. this place is full of wonderful merchants who honestly take the time to share their lives with the visitors whom walk the isles. We have been to this place a few times and cherish each visit as we are eagerly finding something special to discuss about beautiful New Brunswick. The tea...

If an area can be experienced through its cuisine, then a visit to the Old City Market is like a visit to the St. John culture. Three aisles of stands hold the expected fruit and vegetables, meat and cheeses, fresh bakery items, and seafood for the locals. Other stands display t-shirts, sweatshirts, and knick-knacks for the tourists. The aisles are...

It's just a big mall, with a somewhat pricy market at one end of it, nothing special, really. The food at Asian Palace (the Indian restaurant) wasn't very good - worse than in all other Indian restaurants I've ever been to. There is an internet cafe with especially good rates for students and a good Nygard outlet. Other than that...
